Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: A relaxed evening lies ahead with no other commitments.
Story: It’s Friday evening, and the house is finally quiet. I settle onto my bed, the Quran resting on my lap, its familiar pages inviting me to recite and reflect. I’ve been looking forward to this all week—a rare evening with no schoolwork, no chores, just time for myself and my faith. As I begin to read, my phone buzzes. It’s a reminder: “Call Mom and Dad.” My step-parents expect me to check in every week, to share updates and ask about their health. They say it’s important to keep the family close, especially since I’m not their biological child. I know how much it means to them, and I don’t want to disappoint. But tonight, I crave the peace of my own company, the comfort of my faith. My heart tugs in two directions—toward the duty of family, and the spiritual nourishment I desperately need. I stare at the phone, torn, the words of the Quran blurring as I wrestle with what to do next.
